conversations.content: Legends say dragon lairs are full of treasure, and it's true that the creatures often seek riches as tribute from humans.
Why are these sacred beasts so attracted to all that glitters? Some claim it's because dragons once lived among the twinkling stars.
Dragons alighted upon this land many eons ago, yet objects that remind them of their ancient home still bring them solace.
Whether or not this is true, no one knows—not even the dragons themselves.
Many years ago, a hatchling sought to verify the claim that dragons came from beyond the heavens, and so set out to see them for himself.
Still, just because he had wings didn't mean he was able to reach the stars.
The hatchling had many friends, and they flocked to watch his attempts. So he gathered them up, pointed skyward, and said, ＂We'll get there together!＂
The hatchling gathered his friends and devised a plan: they would all ride on each other's shoulders, and the one on the bottom would fly as high as possible.
When that hatchling grew tired, he'd break off and let the next one take over. That way, the last hatchling would be able to reach the stars.
His plan worked. And when the hatchling saw the canopy of stars, he let out an exalted cry.
But he had made one miscalculation: because he was flying at full speed, there was no way to stop.
With a mighty yelp, he collided right into the moon. And that is why, to this day, the craters on the moon form the shape of a dragon.
Many versions of this tale have been told all over southern Grastaea.
Scholars dismiss it as nothing more than a myth, and yet the story gives children cause to dream of the wider world around them.
